title: Unity In Diversity: A Misunderstood Concept
text:
1 Corinthians 10
KJV
15 I speak as to wise men; judge ye what I say.

16+ The cup of blessing which we bless, is it not the communion of the blood of Christ? The bread which we break, is it not the communion of the body of Christ?

17 For we being many are one bread, and one body: for we are all partakers of that one bread.

It was at one Sunday morning bible class that these verses came to mind when I observed the diverse views and opinions that members expressed with passion and held firmly to themselves! It was an incident that remained with me.

Some were willing to accommodate the views of others saying “You’ll one day come to understand and appreciate these views that we hold”. Others said “No way “.

They concluded by saying to each other “As your faith is so be it to you “ and heartily shook hands and walked into the main auditorium

After the Bible class, we entered into worship service to take the Lord’s supper. I watched quietly as these members who a short time ago were at each other’s “necks” sat together on the same bench and stretched forth their hands to take both the bread and the wine.

When I sat back to reflect on this incident which always occurs in our bible classes I said to myself these men were divided over views,  opinions, interpretations etc but united as one when it came to the eating of the bread and drinking of the wine. What a beauty to watch.

Their diversities did not go beyond the Lord’s Table. When it came to breaking the Bread and drinking of the Cup they were united in one mind and one spirit.

It dawned on me as has always been the case that there are things that will divide us just as there are those that will unite us. There will always be essentials and non-essentials. The essentials unite the non-essentials divide.

Blessed are those who can spot these and know what to do under each circumstance. You’ve heard this before “ concerning matters of faith unity, in matters of opinion, liberty; in all things charity (love) “.

I loved what I experienced that Sunday and recommend that we see disagreements from these perspectives. There are essentials just as there are non-essentials, there are weightier matters just as there are non-weightier matters.

I pledge never to expend my energy on non-essential matters instead let each hold and have his views and opinions. As was said after the Bible class “As your faith is so be it to you”  I’ll only come in if it is a “ matter of faith “. Otherwise, I'll remain silent.

The apostle Paul said it nicely, read it
2 Timothy 2:23-24
NIV
[23] Don't have anything to do with foolish and stupid arguments, because you know they produce quarrels.

[24] And the Lord's servant must not be quarrelsome but must be kind to everyone, able to teach, not resentful.

My take

John Franklin Tamakloe

title: The Pilgrim’s Sacred Duty
text:
Psalms 119
KJV
54+ Thy statutes have been my songs in the house of my pilgrimage.

As a pilgrim, the psalmist made the statutes of the Lord his daily theme lest he forgets that he is on a pilgrimage! The same applies to those who read and meditate daily on the Word.

To remind ourselves that we are pilgrims traveling through the land may we not let His Word die out from our lips.

Read and meditate on it every day. The psalmist composed them into songs which he sings daily!
May we also do likewise! Sing at least a song each day.!

Today I sang and meditated on the words of this hymn ;

O God, our help in ages past,
Our hope for years to come,
Our shelter from the stormy blast,
And our eternal home.

Under the shadow of Thy throne
Thy saints have dwelt secure;
Sufficient is Thine arm alone,
And our defence is sure.

Before the hills in order stood,
Or Earth received her frame,
From everlasting Thou art God,
To endless years the same.

A thousand ages in Thy sight
Are like an evening gone;
Short as the watch that ends the night
Before the rising sun.

Time, like an ever-rolling stream,
Bears all its sons away;
They fly forgotten, as a dream
Dies at the opening day.

O God, our help in ages past,
Our hope for years to come,
Be Thou our guard while life shall last,
And our eternal home.

This is a pilgrim’s sacred duty to remind himself of the fleeting nature of time. Have you sung a song this morning?

John Franklin Tamakloe.

title: The Question Of Alliances
text:
Proverbs 28
KJV
4+ They that forsake the law praise the wicked: but such as keep the law contend with them.

An incident took place in which I was involved and the outcome and reactions of those present brought home to me this truth expressed by the writer of the proverb

Proverbs 28:4
NIV
[4] Those who forsake instruction praise the wicked, but those who heed it resist them.

The issue of alliances has always plagued our society, whether spiritual or secular. We are either for or against someone or something.

There are only two alliances in life either a righteous or an evil partnership there is no middle ground;  even to be indifferent is an alliance.

As the writer said those who forsake the law praise the wicked ( law breakers ) but those who uphold it ( principled ) resist or contend against them.

In my dealing with people and issues I have observed over the years that those who do wrong have more support ( fans) than those who do right as  a result they end up having more enemies than wrongdoers

You see this on the road, someone stops in the middle of the road for no proper cause or reason, and you slow down to correct him; some blow their horns, while others shout at you to leave him!

Or you see something that is being done or said etc; which is contrary to the law or the truth; you attempt to correct or draw attention to what the law says! Most present take sides with the lawless!

A pickpocket was arrested and instead of those present to help take him to the police station they rather asked that you leave him once you’ve gotten your purse. Only for him to pick up another’s purse a few hours later.

You know and have experienced similar situations! Wrongdoers win the support of many, this explains why our society is plagued with evil despite the existence of many religious faiths.

Our society, congregations,  workplaces, etc are what they are as a result of the alliances we form! They reflect the type of alliances that exist.

An upright, strong, progressive and prosperous society, congregation, workplace etc is one where righteous alliances outweigh the unrighteous!

Is this not what the proverbs writer meant when he wrote ;
Proverbs 14
KJV
34 Righteousness exalteth a nation: but sin is a reproach to any people.

If those who uphold the principles of truth are more than those who support lies and liars our society, church, workplace etc will be loving, kind, peaceful and prosperous.

So be careful what alliances you form, with whom; where your loyalty lies etc. The choice is yours and remember so are the consequences! What a man sows that also he reaps!

Proverbs 1:10-11,13-15
NIV
[10] My son, if sinful men entice you, do not give in to them. [11] If they say, “Come along with us; let's lie in wait for innocent blood, let's ambush some harmless soul;

[13] we will get all sorts of valuable things and fill our houses with plunder; [14] cast lots with us; we will all share the loot ”--- [15] my son, do not go along with them, do not set foot on their paths;

A word to the wise

John Franklin Tamakloe
